title-group.article-title: A multi-axial fatigue model for fiber-reinforced composite laminates based on Puck’s criterion

contrib-group.aff: 1Department of Mechanical Engineering, National University of Singapore, Singapore.

author-notes.corresp: X.S. Sun, Department of Mechanical Engineering, National University of Singapore, 9 Engineering Drive 1, Singapore 117576, Singapore Email: mpesx@nus.edu.sg

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2011 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: A new multi-axial fatigue model for fiber-reinforced composite laminates based on Puck’s criterion is proposed in this article. In the fatigue model, fatigue master curves from the ATM are used to determine the uniaxial ply fatigue strengths and the multi-axial fatigue failure is then determined by Puck’s criterion with the fatigue strengths at the ply level. The fatigue master curves from ATM are generated with limited uniaxial fatigue tests and can be applied to fatigue loading conditions with various frequencies and stress ratios. Both uniaxial and multi-axial S-N curves can be derived from thefatigue model. Fatigue failure envelopes are also generated from the model to better interpret the multi-axial fatigue failure in multi-axial stress spaces. The proposed multi-axial fatigue model is based on ply-level predictions, but it can beextended to laminate-level predictions with the CLT or numerical methods such as the FEM. Multi-axial fatigue failures caused by either local or global multi-axiality can be predicted by the model. Both uniaxial and biaxial fatigue experimentswere carried out to provide test data for establishing and validating the proposed fatigue model. The application oftheproposed multi-axial fatigue model is demonstrated with predictions of S-N curves and fatigue failure envelopes of unidirectional laminates and multi-directional laminates with typical lay-up configurations. The predictions from the proposed fatigue model are also compared with various experimental results and reasonably good agreement is observed.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
Wind turbine blades made of composites experience multi-axial fatigue loadings when in operation, and therefore fatigue analysis is necessary and important for the design and optimization of blades. Fatigue of composites is usually much more complicated than that of traditional homogenous materials such as metals because both the material properties and the failure of composites are affected by anisotropy and multi-axiality. Thus the development of fatigue models for composites is attracting interest of both researchers and engineers. Many fatigue models for composite materials have been developed over the years, and may be classed into three broad categories:1
Fatigue life models based on the well-known S-N curves and fatigue failure criteria.
Phenomenological residual stiffness/strength models, which employ some evolution laws that describe thegradual deterioration of the stiffness or strength.
Progressive damage models, which consider local damage mechanisms and use one or more quantifiable damage variables related to damage descriptions such as transverse crack density, delamination size, etc.

However, most of these models are formulated for uniaxial loading and not extendable to multi-axial loading conditions. In the fatigue failure models based on S-N curves, the fatigue strengths are determined from S-N curves which must be determined by experiments with defined load frequency and stress ratio. If structure or load information changes, S-N curves usually need to be redetermined by more experiments for this kind of fatigue models. Atypical example is a semi-log S-N curve2,3 with linear relationship between the applied cyclic stress and the number of cycles to failure. The multi-axiality is indicated by two axial ratios in the formula for the curve. A similar S-N curve was also adopted by Philippidis andVassilopoulos4 to fit fatigue strength data with a Tsai-Wu-based fatigue failure criterion under multi-axial stress. Huang5 used the maximum normal stress criterion with S-N curves for a plain-woven fabric reinforced composite subjected to biaxial cyclic loads. Recently, Gude et al.6 modified Puck’s criterion with a group of semi-log S-N curves obtained from linear regression analysis of various test data for prediction ofmulti-axial fatigue failure of carbon/epoxy tubular composites under tension/compression-torsion fatigue loads.

The phenomenological residual stiffness/strength models indirectly qualify the damage accumulation during fatigue. These fatigue models are usually more complicated, ranging from mainly empirical curve fits to more sophisticated damage evolution functions linking residual stiffness to damage variables and loading cycles. An example is due to Kawakami et al.7 who proposed a fatigue damage accumulation model for plain woven glass fabric polymer composite based on continuum damage mechanics, where the modulus decay ratios in tension and shear were used as indicators for damage variables. Under proportional combined tension-torsion loadings, this model is reported to be able to predict fatigue lives for different biaxial stress ratios. Van Paepegem and Degrieck8 presented aphenomenological residual stiffness model that provides the stiffness degradation and permanent strain under generalized in-plane fatigue loading. This model takes into account the actual stress state, but complicated damage growth rate equations, which generally vary with different materials, are used to interpret damage evolutions. Extensive experiments and numerical simulations are required to validate the model. Kawai9 developed a phenomenological fatigue model for the off-axis fatigue behavior of unidirectional (UD) polymer matrix composites, where a new non-dimensional effective stress that considers the effects of the stress ratio and multi-axial state of stress is defined for the evolution of fatigue damage. However, an empirical fatigue strength ratio was used in this model, which requires fatigue experimental data to determine the appropriate quantity. Passipoularidis and Philippidis10 proposed a statistical fatigue model based on a strength degradation scheme named Strength-Life Equal Rank Assumption (SLERA), where several degradation models are studied and large experimental data sets are required for implementation of the complicated model.

An example of a progressive damage approach is given by Shokrieh and Lessard11–14 who proposed a generalized residual material property degradation model for fiber-reinforced composite laminates. They used experimental data from an off-axis UD laminate under uniaxial fatigue in order to predict the behavior of a ply in multi-axial fatigue environment. This modelis complex and integrates stress analysis, failure analysis, and material property degradation rules. Diaoet al.15 incorporated statistics into the above model to study the fatigue failure of fiber-reinforced composite laminates subjected to multi-axial loading, where a Weibull distribution function of material strengths was fitted by experimental data. In general, such a model, however, requires more distribution functions corresponding to the stochastic variables considered. Liu and Mahadevan16 proposed another S-N curve-based fatigue progressive damage model for multi-directional (MD) composite laminates. However, only constant amplitude fatigue loading was considered in this model, and the model was not validated for different stress ratios. Quaresimin et al.17 recently assessed several typical multi-axial fatigue models and proposed an approach based on damage mechanics to develop life predictions for multi-axial fatigue of composites, where failure mechanisms including fiber failure (FF), rectangular cracking and matrix damage from shear deformation are considered. Passipoularidis et al.18 also developed a progressive damage model for fatigue life prediction of composites under block and spectrum loading, where Puck’s criterion was used to determine fatigue failure and uniaxial and/ormulti-axial load timeseries can be simulated. Fatiguemodels based on progressive damage analysis are generally more computationally expensive and complicated.

All the above three categories of fatigue models arebased on traditional fatigue tests, which generally require very costly and substantial amounts of testing at numerous load ratios and frequencies to generate huge experimental fatigue failure databases for the determination of the required empirical parameters. This article proposes a multi-axial fatigue model based on fatigue master curves and Puck’s criterion. Only limited uniaxial fatigue tests of UD laminates are required to generate the master curves and the multi-axial fatigue failure is determined by Puck’s criterion with uniaxial ply fatigue strengths obtained from the fatigue master curves. The traditional S-N curves can be derived and generated from the proposed fatigue model. In the following sections, the proposed multi-axial fatigue model is introduced in detail, and then uniaxial and biaxial fatigue experiments are carried out to provide necessary test data for the proposed model. Finally, predictions of S-N curves and fatigue failure envelopes under multi-axial fatigue loadings are demonstrated and compared with test data for both UD and MD laminates with typical lay-up configurations.

sec.title: The multi-axial fatigue model based on Puck’s criterion
sec.p: The proposed multi-axial fatigue model consists of twoparts: the first establishes fatigue master curves from accelerated testing methodology (ATM)19 which accounts for the uniaxial ply strengths under fatigue loadings (i.e. uniaxial ply fatigue strengths); the second is the prediction of multi-axial fatigue failure using Puck’s criterion. Generally, multi-axial stress states often arise in composite laminates due to the material anisotropy, and hence a local multi-axiality at the plylevel can exist even under uniaxial loading (such as off-axis uniaxial loading). This article will consider a more general multi-axial situation which includes both local and global (external) multi-axialities.

sec.title: Fatigue master curves and S-N curves
sec.p: In the proposed fatigue model, the uniaxial ply fatigue strengths are determined with fatigue master curves. The fatigue master curve is established by the Time-Temperature Superposition Principle (TTSP) in ATM under ply-level uniaxial loadings. With fatigue master curves, the long-term fatigue life of composites can be described in wide ranges of loading and environmental conditions.19 The fatigue master curve at ambient temperature is obtained from master curves in the short-term tests with elevated temperature conditions and can be generally formulated as:19 (1) where σf, f, t are variables denoting the uniaxial fatigue failure stress, frequency, and time to failure, respectively; σs,0 is the constant strain rate (CSR) strength at the initial reduced time; t1 is the transient reduced time at the reference temperature, which denotes a time when the material turns to a glassy phase; nr, nc, nf are exponent parameters determined by fitting test data.19

Consider the relationship t = Nf / f and substituting it into Equation (1), σf can also be formulated as a function of frequency f and number of cycles to failureNf.19 Usually, the fatigue master curve is based on some certain values of stress ratio R = σmin / σmax and a generalized fatigue master curve for different stress ratios can be obtained by introducing a coefficient gf such that: (2a) or the normalized fatigue master curve: (2b) where: (3) (4) (5)

Here, - 1 ≤ r < 1 is a load amplitude ratio and ‘sgn’ denotes the sign function; r0 = R0 if 0 ≤ R0 < 1 and r0 = 1 / R0 if R0 > 1, where R and R0 are the stress ratios in the actual and reference states, respectively, with R0 ≥ 0. With the empirical coefficient gf which accounts for the effect of mean and alternating stresses relative to the reference state, the defined fatigue master curve in Equation (2) is suitable for loading conditions with various load frequencies and stress ratios. For given load frequencies or stress ratios, typical normalized fatigue master curves from Equation (2b) may be plotted in Figure 1(a) or (b), respectively. In general, higher frequencies will result in greater strength degradation in the same time to failure. Figure 1.
Normalized fatigue master curves: (a) for different frequencies and (b) for different stress ratios.

Analogously to Equation (1), Equation (2) can also be formulated by using the variable Nf and the relationship t = Nf / f. To establish a consistent relationship between the fatigue failure stress σf and the corresponding static failure stress, or static strength, σ0, assume that σf can be simplified to σ0 when Nf = f · t = 1 / 2, so that a relationship between σ s, 0 and σ0 is obtained by substituting Nf = 1 / 2 into Equation (2a): (6) where: (7)

It can be seen that the fatigue master curve in Equation (2) is determined by the corresponding static failure stress σ0, transient reduced time t1, reference stress ratio R0, and exponent parameters nr, nc, and Nf. In this article, the reference stress ratio R0in the fatigue master curve is selected from limited uniaxial fatigue tests of UD laminates, and the parameters (t1, nr, nc, and Nf) are then obtained by fitting curve with these limited fatigue test data.

For a constant load frequency and using the relationship Nf = f · t, the traditional uniaxial S-N curve can be recovered from the fatigue master curve formulation of Equation (2a): (8) where the parameters n1 and n2 are obtained from nc, nf, and gf through the following: (9)

For composite materials, the static failure stress σ0 isusually different for tension and compression, andtherefore the value of σ0 in Equation (6) can be either tensile strength σ0, T} or compressive strength σ0, C, or both, depending on the value of stress ratio R, thatis: (10) where: (11)

For R > 1 or R < 0, the absolute value of stress is used in the master curve. Equation (10) indicates that there are two master curves for R < 0, that is, tensile and compressive master curves corresponding to σ0, T and σ0, C, respectively. In this case, the fatigue failure is determined by the master curve with lower stress for a given time or number of cycles to failure, which indicates that the failure may be caused by tension or compression. As shown in Figure 2, if the tensile and compressive master curves intersect at point (ta, σf, a), the failure is dominated by compression under stress higher than σf, a and by tension under stress lower than σf, a. However, if the tensile and compressive master curves intersect at no point, which means thetensile master curve is always above or below the compressive master curve, the failure is always determined by the master curve with lower stress. It is also interesting to note three special cases for R < 0:
R = - 1 and therefore Δσ0, C = Δσ0T = 0.
R → 0- (left limit) and therefore Δσ0,C → ∞ which indicates that the failure is dominated by tension.
R → - ∞ and therefore Δσ0, T} → ∞ which indicates that the failure is dominated by compression.
Figure 2.
Fatigue master curves for R < 0.

The fatigue master curve defined in Equation (2a) is a deterministic formulation and the influence of the failure probability is not considered. The fatigue test data are often scattered and the tests are somewhat not deterministic (specimens may not fail or run out), and statistical methods with failure probability are usually adopted in some fatigue analyses of composites.10,15–17 An additional statistical term Kf may be considered in the fatigue master curve,19 and a statistical formulation of the fatigue master curve can be written as: (12) (13) where Pf is failure probability and αf is a Weibull shape parameter of test data.19

In Equation (13), if the failure probability Pf = 63.2%, then Kf = 1 and consequently the influence of the failure probability vanishes in Equation (12). Inthis case, the statistical formulation defined in Equation (12) is simplified to the deterministic formulation defined in Equation (2a). If different failure probability is considered, for example, Pf = 10% or 90%, the predicted results from the statistical model will become more conservative or optimistic than those from the deterministic model, and a region will be predicted to represent scattered test data. A more reasonable method to obtain the value of αf is to fit a linear Weibull plot of test data. While the Weibull plot is indicated to be generated with static strength tests insome literatures,10 it can be better generated with uniaxial fatigue tests under the same stress level. Since it requires multiple specimens tested under a fixed stresslevel to obtain a proper Weibull parameter, this article will only focus on the deterministic formulation defined in Equation (2a), and the statistical formulation may be further developed and evaluated in future separate work.

sec.title: Fatigue failure determination with Puck’s criterion
sec.p: Puck’s failure criterion is an action-plane-related strength criterion at the macro stress (ply stress) level, which consists of two basically independent fracture conditions: a FF condition and an inter-fiber failure (IFF) condition.20–22 The FF condition is based on a modified maximum strain failure criterion considering a stress magnification effect and a shear correction, and the IFF condition is based on a modified Mohr hypothesis, that is, the IFF is influenced only by the stresses onthe fracture plane (an inclined plane parallel to the fibers and determined by a fracture angle). The action-plane-related strengths used in Puck’s criterion are generally determined by basic uniaxial ply strengths. With the fatigue master curve defined in Equation (2a), the uniaxial ply fatigue strengths including longitudinal tension and compression, transverse tension and compression, and in-plane shear, that is, XT, f, XC, f YT, f, YC, f and S12, f, can be obtained for a fixed constant frequency and time or number of cycles to failure. These uniaxial ply fatigue strengths can be incorporated into Puck’s criterion, where the static strengths are replaced by the fatigue strengths, and subsequently the fatigue failure under any multi-axial loading can be predicted. Basedon Puck’s criterion, the general multi-axial fatigue failure criterion can be formulated as the following: (14) where FPis the function of Puck’s criterion which is usually determined by the fracture plane,22 and Sk, f(R, f, t) is the uniaxial ply fatigue strength for a given stress ratio R, load frequency f, and time to failure t; i = 1, 2, 3, 12, 23, 13 with fatigue stress components σ12, f = τ12, f, σ23, f = τ23, f, and σ13, f = τ13, f k = 1, 2, …, 5 with uniaxial ply fatigue strengths S1, f = XT, f, S2, f = XC, f, S3, f = YT, f, S4, f = YC, f, and S5, f = S12, f.

Alternatively, Equation (14) can also be formulated with the number of cycles to failure Nf considering the relationship t = Nf / f. The multi-axial fatigue failure criterion defined in Equation (14) may be applied to generate fatigue failure envelopes for a given stress ratio R, load frequency f, and time to failure t or number of cycles to failure Nf. Similar to Puck’s criterion for static analysis, the multi-axial fatigue version is also ply-level based. Analysis methods such as the classical lamination theory (CLT) or the finite element method (FEM) are needed for fatigue failure analysis of MD laminates.

sec.title: Equivalent fatigue stress and multi-axial S-N curves
sec.p: The S-N curve defined in Equation (8) cannot be directly used in multi-axial fatigue loadings where multiple fatigue stress components must be considered. Therefore, a method to determine the multi-axial S-N curve is further developed with the above mentioned fatigue model. Towards this end, a scalar equivalent fatigue stress σeq is defined with a general multi-axial stress σ or multi-axiality ratios λi as the following: (15) where (16) (17)

Here, the superscript ‘T’ denotes transpose of an array; i = 1, 2, 3, 12, 23, 13 (with σ12 = τ12, σ23 = τ23, and σ13 = τ13) for UD laminates or plies (the coordinates system is defined in local material directions), and i = x, y, z, xy, yz, xz (with σxy = τxy, σyz = τyz, and σxz = τxz) for MD laminates (the coordinates system is defined in global reference directions); σN is the first non-zero stress component of σ, for example, σN = σ1 if σ1 ≠ 0 for UD laminates. It should be noted that the definition of multi-axiality ratios λi in Equation (17) implies a positive or negative value of the corresponding stress component σi, which corresponds to tension or compression in some loading cases. Agroup of multi-axiality ratios [λ] comprises the multi-axiality ratios λi covering all stress components in a given stress space.

Under multi-axial fatigue loading σ = σf,(R, f, Nf), the equivalent fatigue stress can be determined from Equation (15) as σeq = σeq, f (R, f, Nf). The multi-axial fatigue stress σf(R, f, Nf) can be obtained with the above mentioned fatigue model and given multi-axiality ratios, that is: (18) where FPis the function of Puck’s criterion under fatigue loadings; i, j = 1, 2, 3, 12, 23, 13(i ≠ j) with fatigue stress components σ12, f = τ12, f, σ23, f = τ23, f, and σ13, f = τ13, f.

Once the multi-axial fatigue stress for a given stress ratio R and load frequency f, σf, (Nf), is determined with Equation (18), the multi-axial S-N curve which accounts for the effect of all fatigue stress components, σeq, f,(Nf) = σeq, f} σf(Nf)), can be obtained through the equivalent fatigue stress defined by Equation (15). However, this multi-axial S-N curve cannot be explicitly formulated but is usually numerically obtained from Equations (15) and (18). It can be verified that the multi-axial S-N curve determined from Equations (15) and (18) can be reduced to the uniaxial one explicitly defined in Equation (8) under uniaxial loading. Inthe current multi-axial fatigue model, the multi-axial fatigue stress σf(R, f, Nf) corresponds to thestress state causing fatigue failure and therefore itis the multi-axial fatigue strength Σf, that is, Σf = σf(R, f, Nf) and Σeq, f} = σeq, f(R, f, Nf) The multi-axial fatigue strength Σf is generally used in the context of a given group of multi-axiality ratios.

sec.title: Implementation of the multi-axial fatigue model
sec.p:
An Excel-based user-friendly interface was developed for implementing the multi-axial fatigue model and fatigue analysis of UD or MD laminates. With the input ply material properties (Young’s moduli and static strengths, etc.) and fatigue load information (stress ratio, frequency, multi-axiality ratios, number of cycles or time to failure, etc.), the multi-axial fatigue strength Σf for a given group of multi-axiality ratios and a number of cycles or time to failure can be computed from the fatigue model. Fatigue failure envelopes for a given number of cycles or time to failure and S-N curves for a given group of multi-axiality ratios can also be generated and plotted. The flowchart for implementing the multi-axial fatigue model is illustrated in Figure 3. The fatigue master curves can be generated from limited uniaxial fatigue tests and the corresponding parameters can be stored for analysis of the same composite materials. For simplicity but without loss of generality, the fatigue failure envelope for a number of cycles or time to failure is plotted with the same load amplitude ratio R for all loading axes but possible different stress ratio R, because the multi-axial loads may alternate between tension and compression for varying multi-axiality ratios. Nevertheless, this is not a prerequisite for the multi-axial fatigue model and different load amplitude ratios R for loading axes may be considered in the model. Figure 3.
Flowchart for implementing the multi-axial fatigue model.

For UD laminates, the multi-axial fatigue strength Σf is directly determined by Puck’s criterion with uniaxial fatigue strengths obtained from the fatigue master curves. For MD laminates, the multi-axiality ratios arebased on global reference directions and should be transformed to the local multi-axiality ratios in theply material directions, and the stress ratio R is same for local ply directions and global reference directions. Fatigue failure predictions are based on the last-ply-failure (LPF) theory, as shown in Figure 4. Indetermining the multi-axial fatigue strength Σf of MD laminates by Puck’s criterion based on LPF, usually a progressive degradation based on ply-by-ply discount is required to calculate the degraded laminate stiffness after first-ply-failure (FPF). For laminates with uniform ply stress distribution, however, a simultaneous degradation scheme can be used to simplify the failure analysis.23 In this article, only laminates with uniform ply stress distribution are considered for demonstrating the multi-axial fatigue model, and therefore the simultaneous degradation scheme is used. Nevertheless, the proposed model is straightforward to laminates with non-uniform stress distribution (such as laminates with an open hole) with progressive damage analysis based on numerical methods such as FEM. In the simultaneous degradation scheme, three potential failure patterns are considered, i.e. the FPF pattern where the laminate stiffness D¯ is based on intact materials, the LPF-matrix pattern where the laminate stiffness D¯m is based on materials with degraded matrix, and the LPF-fiber pattern where the laminate stiffness D¯f is based on materials with degraded fibers. A coefficient dm = df = 0.01 is used in the degradation of matrix or fiber material to calculate the degraded laminate stiffness (D¯m or D¯f). The degradation of matrix or fibers is simultaneous for allplies, and therefore no iteration is required in the computation. The stress distribution based on the laminate stiffness D¯ or the stress redistribution based on the degraded laminate stiffness (D¯m or D¯f) in each ply is calculated by Puck’s criterion with CLT for the three failure patterns, respectively. The laminate failure stress for each pattern is the minimum value of failure stresses in all plies, and the final laminate failure stress (the multi-axial fatigue strength) is the maximum value of failure stresses from the three patterns. Figure 4.
Flowchart for determining the multi-axial fatigue strength of MD laminates by CLT and Puck’s criterion with a simultaneous degradation scheme.

The current fatigue model is focused on predicting the ultimate laminate strength under fatigue loading, and only constant amplitude fatigue loading is considered in the article. Although the variable amplitude fatigue may arise due to stress redistributions caused by ply failures and stiffness degradation for MD laminates, the amplitude can be assumed to be constant for each failure pattern with the simultaneous degradation scheme (Figure 4), and the final failure stress or strength is determined by the maximum value corresponding to the stress state in plies.

sec.title: Fatigue experiments
sec.p: Both uniaxial and biaxial fatigue tests were carried outunder constant stress amplitude using a universal testing machine INSTRON 8501. The uniaxial fatigue tests are used to generate fatigue master curves for the proposed multi-axial fatigue model and the biaxial fatigue tests are used to demonstrate the applicability of the model.

sec.title: Uniaxial static and fatigue tests
sec.p:
The proposed multi-axial fatigue model is based on ply-level predictions and therefore the ply material properties and static strengths are required in the application of themodel. In this article, glass/epoxy UD laminates (eight plies, i.e. [0]8) were tested to provide the ply material properties and static strengths for the current fatigue tests which are used to establish and demonstratethe multi-axial fatigue model. The laminates were manufactured in infused glass fibers with fiber volume fraction Vf = 65%. The geometry and dimensions (in mm) of the UD test coupons with end tabs are shown in Figure 5. The coupons were cut from UD laminate panels using water jet cutting method. For longitudinal compressive tests, L = 20 mm and W = 25 mm; for longitudinal tensile tests, L = 40 mm and W = 11 mm, where the width of the test coupons was reduced from the standard 25 mm to the current 11 mm due to the loadcell capacity (±100 kN) of INSTRON 8501. Nevertheless, a comparison test has been performed and the results show that both Young’s modulus and strength of the coupons with width 11 mm are consistently similar to those coupons with width 25 mm. Figure 5.
Geometry and dimensions (in mm) of the UD test coupons with end tabs.

The static tensile tests of glass/epoxy UD laminates were performed according to EN ISO 527-424 using INSTRON 8501 (load cell capacity: ±100 kN), and the compressive tests were performed according to ASTM D3410/D3410M25 using Shimazu universal testing machine (load cell capacity: ±250 kN). Strain was recorded using two single strain gauges attached on thecentral area of the coupons, one on each face. The uniaxial static test results are listed in Tables 1 and 2, respectively, where the fiber material properties and the ply shear and transverse compressive strengths are not tested but referred to the values of typical glass/epoxy materials from the ‘World-Wide Failure Exercise (WWFE)’.26 Table 1.
Material properties of the glass/epoxy UD laminate
Material properties Ply Fiberb
Longitudinal modulus E1 (GPa) 48.7 74.0
Transverse moduli E2 = E3 (GPa) 16.8 74.0
Shear moduli G12 = G13 (GPa) 5.83a 30.8
Shear modulus G23 (GPa) 6.00 30.8
Poisson’s ratios v12 = v13 0.28 0.20
Poisson’s ratio v23 0.40b 0.20
a
Initial modulus. Secant modulus at shear failure strain G12s = 1.95 GPa. b
Values referred to the material in Word-Wide Failure Exercise.26
Table 2.
Uniaxial static strengths of the glass/epoxy UD laminate
Ply strengths Values
Longitudinal tensile strength XT (MPa) 1170
Longitudinal compressive strength XC (MPa) 977
Transverse tensile strength YT (MPa) 30.5
Transverse compressive strength YC (MPa) 114a
Shear strength S12 (MPa) 72.0a
a
Values referred to the material in Word-Wide Failure Exercise.26

The limited uniaxial fatigue tests of glass/epoxy UD laminate [0]8 were carried out for three values of stress ratio R = 0.1, 10, - 1, respectively. The geometry and dimensions of the fatigue test coupons are similar to those for static tests, as shown in Figure 5, with L = 40 mm for R = 0.1 and L = 20 mm for R = 10, − 1; W = 11 mm for all uniaxial fatigue test coupons. To get good bonding surfaces, peel plies of the coupons and endtabs were removed just before the bonding, and a proper adhesive with high durability (3M-DP420 black) was used to bond the coupon and tabs in the fatigue tests. All the coupons were tested using INSTRON 8501 under sinusoidal loads with frequency f = 4Hz. The uniaxial test data obtained for R = 0.1 and R = 10 are used to generate the fatigue master curves (asshown in Figure 9). The uniaxial fatigue test dataobtained for R = - 1 are plotted in Figure 11 for comparison with predictions from the proposed fatigue model.

sec.title: Biaxial fatigue tests
sec.p:
The biaxial fatigue tests were performed using a biaxialfixture mounted on INSTRON 8501 (Figure 6). Acruciform type specimen was set up on the biaxial fixture. The center of the cruciform specimen (biaxial zone) was milled to reduce the thickness from 7.14 mm (32 plies in arms) to 1.78 mm (8 plies in the central biaxial zone), as shown in Figures 7(a) and 8(a). The area of the biaxial zone is about 18 × 18 mm2. The cruciform geometry is selected from the optimum type designed by Smits et al.27 This geometry has a reduced thickness in the central region of the specimen, in combinationwith a fillet corner between two arms inside the material. These features cause failure to occur in the biaxially loaded test zone, rather than in the uniaxially loaded arms. Additionally, the uniformity of the strain field in the central zone was also checked using finite element analysis and digital image correlation technique. Lamkanfi et al.28–30 found that cruciform specimen type of Smits et al.27 may still lead to unwanted stress concentrations at the inner radius of the arms under certain conditions. They suggested the use of a continuous spline for the arms to replace the inner radius. However, as an alternative, in this article, the thickness of the cruciform arms was instead made much thicker than the thickness of the biaxial zone in order to ensure higher stresses in the biaxial zone. The ratio of the thicknesses of the arm to the biaxial zone is 4:1, which is much higher than the specimen of Smits et al.27 which is 1.8:1. Figure 6.
Biaxial fatigue test with cruciform specimen and biaxial fixture mounted on INSTRON 8501. Figure 7.
Photographs of off-axis specimen ([45/−45]4 laminate; σx = 71.7MPa, σy = - 8.53MPa): (a) Nf = 0 (before loading), (b)Nf = 4944 (visible failure), (c) Nf = 8902 (final failure), and (d) after final failure. Figure 8.
Photographs of cross-ply specimen ([0/90]4 laminate; σx = 269.9MPa, σy = - 240.6MPa): (a) Nf = 0 (before loading), (b)Nf = 14364 (visible failure), (c) Nf = 14453 (final failure) and (d) after final failure.

The biaxial loadings are achieved through the biaxial fixture under a vertical loading by the INSTRON actuator. For example, if the actuator moves upwards, the cruciform specimen will experience compression in the vertical direction and tension in the horizontal direction, and vice versa, as indicated by the white arrows in Figure 6. The horizontal and vertical directions correspond to the x and y directions in a global reference coordinates system, respectively. The biaxiality ratio between the horizontal and vertical loads was determined by the angle of link bars in the fixture. Strains in both horizontal and vertical directions were recorded using three strain gauges (strain rosettes) attached to the central area (biaxial zone) of the specimens as shown in Figures 7(a) and 8(a). The biaxial fatigue tests were carried out under sinusoidal loads with frequency f = 4 Hz, and stress ratio R = 10 for vertical loading and R = 0.1 for horizontal loading. Two kinds of glass/epoxy MD laminates including off-axis laminate (lay-up configuration: [45/−45]4) and cross-ply laminate (lay-up configuration: [0/90]4) were tested under biaxial loads. Figures 7(b)–(d) and 8(b)–(d) show the photograph of the biaxial fatigue specimens for MD [45/−45]4 and [0/90]4 laminates before and after final failure (fracture), respectively.

Five and ten specimens were tested under different stress levels and biaxiality ratios for off-axis and cross-ply laminates, respectively. The biaxial test data are plotted in Figures 18 and 23 for comparison with predictions from the proposed multi-axial fatigue model. Itwas observed that damage started in the biaxial zone of each specimen and no delamination was observed in the arms of the cruciform specimens. For the off-axis specimens ([45/−45]4 laminate), extensive matrix cracking occurred first in the biaxial zone and then followed by fiber failure. For the cross-ply specimens ([0/90]4 laminate), damage clearly started in the biaxial zone of each specimen, and the damage was dominated by fiber failure. The off-axis specimens can still withstand the load for many cycles after the visible matrix cracking occurs as shown in Figure 7(b)–(d), whereas the cross-ply specimens are fractured soon after the visible failure, as shown in Figure 8(b)–(d).

sec.title: Demonstration and application of the fatigue model
sec.p: The fatigue model may be applied to multi-axial fatigue analysis of both UD and MD laminates. In this section, glass/epoxy UD and MD laminates are used to demonstrate the applicability of the proposed multi-axial fatigue model. Master curves of uniaxial fatigue strengths are first obtained from the above mentioned limited uniaxial fatigue tests of glass/epoxy UD laminates before fatigue analysis is performed based on the master curves and Puck’s criterion. For the current fatigue tests, the ply material properties and static strengths used in the demonstration are listed in Tables 1 and 2, respectively, as mentioned in the previous section. Besides the current fatigue tests, various fatigue tests on glass/epoxy laminates in literature, including the well-known OPTIMAT database,31–38 SNL/MSU/DOE database,39 and some published fatigue test data,40 are also used to validate the model, wherethe basic material properties are provided by corresponding static tests.

sec.title: Generation of fatigue master curves with limited uniaxial fatigue tests
sec.p:
For fiber-reinforced UD laminates, five uniaxial ply fatigue strengths (longitudinal tension and compression, transverse tension and compression, and in-plane shear) may be determined from the fatigue master curves. Six parameters from Equation (2a) need to be determined from tests. The CSR strength σs,0 can be obtained by the corresponding static strength σ0 through the relationship in Equation (6), and the other five parameters are determined by fitting data with uniaxial fatigue tests of UD laminates. Figure 9 shows the fitted fatigue master curves of longitudinal tension and compression with the current uniaxial test data of glass/epoxy UD laminates for f = 4Hz, where the values of reference stress ratio R0 = 0.1 and R0 = 10 are used in the fitting data of tension and compression, respectively. The obtained fitting parameters are listed in Table 3. Table 3.
Fitting parameters for fatigue master curves of the glass/epoxy UD laminate
Parameters Tension Compression
t1(min) 5.8 × 108 5.8 × 108
Nf 0.05 0.03
nr 0.20 0.10
nc 0.15 0.11

The fatigue master curves of transverse and shear strengths can also be fitted with corresponding test data. However, in order to simplify the analysis and without loss of generality for application of the fatigue model, it can be assumed that the fitting parameters in the fatigue master curves for transverse tension and compression are same as those for longitudinal tension and compression, respectively, and that the fitting parameters for shear are same as those for tension. Figure 10 shows the fatigue master curves of uniaxial transverse tension/compression and shear with the fitting parameters and corresponding static strengths, based on the reference stress ratios R0 = 0.1 and R0 = 10. With these fatigue master curves, multi-axial fatigue analysis can be implemented and S-N curves, fatigue strengths, or fatigue failure envelopes can be obtained for given load frequencies, stress ratios, and multi-axiality ratios. Figure 9.
Fitting fatigue master curves of glass/epoxy UD laminates from limited uniaxial test data: (a) longitudinal tension and (b)longitudinal compression. Figure 10.
Fatigue master curves of glass/epoxy UD laminates for the reference stress ratios: transverse tension/compression and shear. Figure 11.
Comparison of predictions of uniaxial S-N curves with the current test data for R = −1.

sec.title: Uniaxial and multi-axial S-N curves
sec.p:
As mentioned in Section 2, both uniaxial and multi-axial S-N curves can be derived from the proposed multi-axial fatigue model, as indicated in Equations (8), (15), and (18). Figures 11–14 plot various uniaxial S-N curves of UD laminates, where the predictions from the fatigue model are compared with test data from different experiments. It can be seen that the theoretical predictions agree reasonably well with the experimental results. The uniaxial S-N curves for different load frequencies are compared in Figure 12, and the comparison shows that the predicted S-N curves change little with load frequencies. Accordingly, a default frequency f = 4Hz is used to plot the S-N curves for simplicity of comparison in Figure 13. Figure 12.
Comparison of predictions of uniaxial S-N curves with test data31,32 for various frequencies: (a) R = 0.1 and (b) R = −1. Figure 13.
Comparison of predictions of uniaxial S-N curves with test data33–35 for various stress ratios: (a) longitudinal direction and (b) transverse direction. Figure 14.
Comparison of predictions of uniaxial S-N curves with test data39 for stress ratio R = 0.1: (a) longitudinal tension and (b)transverse tension.

The uniaxial S-N curves for various stress ratios are also compared in Figures 11–13. The failure for R = - 1 may be caused by compression or tension depending ondifferent stress levels. In the case of longitudinal loading for R = - 1, it is observed from experiments that some specimens failed by compressive buckling and others failed by tension, which corresponds to high and low stress levels in the S-N curves, respectively, as shown in Figures 11, 12(b) and 13(a). In the current fatigue tests for R = - 1, three coupons failed in compression at high stress levels, which correspond to the three datapoints with σf = 679.9MPa and 589.2 MPa in Figure 11, and other coupons failed in tension. In the fatigue tests for R = - 1 by Philippidis et al.34 only two coupons were monitored with slight compressive buckling, which corresponds to the two data points with σf = 344.6MPa and 340.4MPa for R = - 1 in Figure 13(a). The report by Lekou32 only mentioned that some coupons failed in compression for R = - 1, without specific coupon information. Inthe case of transverse loading for R = - 1, however, the failure is usually caused by tension because the transverse tensile strength is much lower than compressive strength and the tensile S-N curve is always below the compressive S-N curve, which can be seen in Figure 13(b).

The comparisons in Figures 11–14 also show that the fatigue test data usually vary with different stress ratios, loading directions (longitudinal or transverse), and static strengths. For example, in the longitudinal fatigue tests for R = - 1, Figures 11, 12(b) and 13(a) show different test data and S-N curves. Generally, for a given number of cycles to failure, the higher the static strength σ0 or mplitude ratio R, higher is the fatigue stress σf. In the current fatigue model, a linear relationship between the static strength and the fatigue stress is used, as indicated in Equation (8).

Figures 15 and 16 plot multi-axial S-N curves of UD laminates for different local multi-axiality ratios (σ1 :σ2 :τ12) and stress ratios (R), and the predictions are also compared with test data which are obtained through transforming fatigue test data of UD off-axis coupons from the loading direction to ply material directions.37,40 The relationship between the local multi-axiality ratios in the material directions and the off-axis angle θ is σ1 :σ2 :τ12 = cos2θ:sin2θ:cosθ sinθ. Itshould be noted that the multi-axial S-N curves in Figures 15 and 16 are generated from Equations (15) and (18) for given multi-axiality ratios, and the corresponding test data are also transformed to the equivalent stress defined in Equation (15). The relationship between the equivalent stress σeq and the off-axis stress σx is: (19) Figure 15.
Comparison of predictions of multi-axial S-N curves for UD laminates with test data34,37 for different local multi-axiality ratios (σ1 :σ2 :τ12). Figure 16.
Comparison of predictions of multi-axial S-N curves for UD laminates with test data40 for different stress ratios: (a)R = 0.5, (b) R = 0, and (c) R = −1.

For comparison, the uniaxial S-N curve (with a special group of local multi-axiality ratios σ1 :σ2 :τ12 = 1:0:0 or σ1 :σ2 :τ12 = 0:1:0) of longitudinal or transverse tension is also plotted. It can be seen that the multi-axial S-N curves vary with different multi-axiality ratios, and therefore a logarithmic scale in the stress ordinate is used to better show the comparison for a wide range of stress values. The comparison shows that the predicted multi-axial S-N curves based on the equivalent stress generally agree with the test data. In Figure 16, the predicted S-N curves in the longitudinal direction (σ1 :σ2 :τ12 = 1:0:0) are a little more conservative than test data, which may be caused by the lower static longitudinal tensile strength (XT = 800MPa). For other multi-axiality ratios in Figure 16, the predictions generally agree well with test data, except for cases with higher transverse stresscomponents (σ2) for stress ratio R = - 1 as shownin Figure 16(c). It should be noted that the compressive S-N curves for R = - 1 are not plotted in Figure 16(c) because the compressive strengths are not available in the test data.40 Nevertheless, the failure for the off-axis tests for R = - 1 can be determined by the tensile S-N curves because it was dominated by the matrix.40

The multi-axial S-N curves for MD laminates are plotted in Figures 17 and 18, and the predictions are also compared with test data. In Figure 17, special global multi-axiality ratios, that is, σx :σy :τxy = ± 1:0:0, are investigated for different MD laminates and different stress ratios, respectively. Although these MD laminates are applied with a global uniaxial load, the failure in theplies is actually caused by local multi-axial stress states. For R = - 1 in Figure 17(a), failure was under tension in all test cases.37 However, the failure mode of tests for R = - 1 by DOE MSU39 was not reported. Thecomparison in Figure 17 shows reasonably good agreement of predictions with test data, which indicates that the ply-level-based multi-axial fatigue model is able to predict fatigue failure of MD laminates. Figure 18 shows biaxial S-N curves of MD laminates, including lay-up configurations of [45/−45/]4 and [0/90]4, for different global biaxiality ratios (σx :σy), f = 4Hz and r = 0.1. For the experiment, the biaxial stresses of the cruciform specimen are estimated from the measured strains and virgin stiffness based on CLT. For the [45/−45]4 laminate, a secant modulus at the failure strain is used to calculate the failure stress in order to circumvent the complication caused by material degradation and non-linearity. For the [0/90]4 laminate, the final failure is dominated by the fibers and the material degradation of matrix usually has no significant influence on the laminate stiffness before fiber failure, and so for simplicity, the failure stress is calculated with virgin stiffness. Based on the comparison with test results in Figure 18, the multi-axial fatigue model reasonably predicts the fatigue failure under biaxial loading despite some optimistic predictions for the MD [0/90]4 laminate as shown in Figure 18(b). Figure 17.
Comparison of predictions of multi-axial S-N curves for MD laminates with test data37-39 under global uniaxial loading (special multi-axiality ratios: σx :σy :τxy = ± 1:0:0) : (a) different lay-ups and (b) different stress ratios.

sec.title: Fatigue failure envelopes
sec.p:
It can be seen from Figures 15–18 that the multi-axial S-N curves can only illustrate multi-axial fatigue failure for given groups of multi-axiality ratios. With the uniaxial ply fatigue strengths obtained from the fatigue master curves or S-N curves for given load frequencies and stress ratios, fatigue failure envelopes can be generated with Puck’s criterion in a given number of cycles or time to failure. Fatigue failure envelopes, however, can illustrate multi-axial fatigue failure for any group of multi-axiality ratios in a defined multi-axial stress space (e.g. Figures 19 and 22). Different failure modes can also be shown in the fatigue failure envelope, which usually cannot be discerned with the multi-axial S-N curves. Using the same test data in Figures 15, 16 and 18, fatigue failure envelopes predicted from the multi-axial fatigue model for given numbers of cycles to failure are plotted in different stress spaces for both UD and MD laminates and compared with the test data (Figures 20, 21, 23). Figure 18.
Comparison of predictions of biaxial S-N curves for MD laminates with the current test data for different global biaxiality ratios (σx :σy): (a) [45/−45]4 laminate and (b) [0/90]4 laminate. Figure 19.
Biaxial fatigue failure envelopes of UD laminates (f = 4 Hz). Figure 20.
Comparison of predictions of fatigue failure envelopes for UD laminates with test data (f = 1.0 ~ 5.2 Hz, R = 0.1)36,37in various stress spaces: (a) stress space σ1 - σ2 with τ12 ≠ 0, (b) stress space σ1 - τ12 with σ2 ≠ 0, and (c) stress space σ2 - τ12 with σ1 ≠ 0. Figure 21.
Comparison of predictions of fatigue failure envelopes for UD laminates with test data (f = 3.3 Hz, R = 0)40 in various stress spaces: (a) stress space σ1 - σ2 (σ1 ≥ 0 and σ2 ≥ 0) with τ12 ≠ 0, (b) stress space σ1 - τ12 (σ1 ≥ 0 and τ12} ≥ 0) with σ2 ≠ 0, and (c) stress space σ2 - τ12 (σ2 ≥ 0 and τ12 ≥ 0) with σ1 ≠ 0. Figure 22.
Biaxial fatigue failure envelopes of MD laminates: (a) [45/−45]4 laminate and (b) [0/90]4 laminate. Figure 23.
Comparison of predictions of fatigue failure envelopes for MD laminates with the current test data in biaxial stress space σx - σy (σx ≥ 0 and σy ≤ 0): (a) [45/−45]4 laminate and (b) [0/90]4 laminate.

sec.title: UD LAMINATES
sec.p: Figure 19 illustrates the fatigue failure envelopes of UD laminates in biaxial stress space σ1 - σ2, for various number of cycles to failure and r = 0.1 (R = 0.1, 10). Basically, the fatigue failure envelope decreases in size with number of cycles to failure because of the decreased fatigue strengths. As shown in Figure 19, biaxial fatigue strength of UD laminates for given biaxiality ratios and a number of cycles to failure can be illustratively determined from the fatigue failure envelopes.

The fatigue failure envelopes of UD laminates for different stress ratios are plotted in various biaxial stress spaces, as shown in Figures 20 and 21, where some of the test results36,37,40 are also included and compared with the predicted failure envelopes. Since the longitudinal and transverse compressive strengths are not available in the test data,40 only parts with σ1 ≥ 0 and σ2 ≥ 0 of the failure envelopes are plotted in Figure 21. The comparison demonstrates that the predictions from the fatigue model generally agree well with the experimental results. It should be noted that Figures 20 and 21 actually plot the multi-axial (tri-axial) failure envelopes in different biaxial stress spacesthrough a sectional view with the non-zero valueof the third stress. For example, Figure 20(a) plots the tri-axial failure envelopes in the σ1 - σ2 stress space with different non-zero values of shear stress τ12. InPuck’s criterion, however, the longitudinalstress σ1 usually has little effect on failure envelopes in stress space σ2 - τ12 if σ1 is not close to the longitudinal tensile or compressive strength. So the failure envelopes in Figures 20(c) and 21(c) with different values of σ1 < < XT (denotes fatigue stress or fatiguestrength in fatigue loading) for each number of cycles are nearly same as the corresponding biaxial σ2 - τ12 failure envelopes with σ1 = 0. The fatigue failure envelopes in Figures 20 and 21 clearly show fatigue failures of UD laminates for various multi-axiality ratios. For example, in Figure 20(c), the fatigue failures for muli-axiality ratios σ1 :σ2 :τ12 = 1:0.03:0.18 (corresponding to 10o off-axis tests)37 and σ1 :σ2 :τ12 = 1:3:1.73 (corresponding to 60o off-axis tests36,37 are mainly dominated by shear and transverse tension, respectively.

sec.title: MD LAMINATES
sec.p: For MD laminates, the last-ply failure (LPF) usually dominates the laminate ultimate strength and is more important in the case of fatigue loadings, and therefore the LPF envelopes are plotted to show the laminate failure characteristics under multi-axial fatigue loadings. Biaxial fatigue failure envelopesare illustrated in Figures 22 and 23, which are generated with the fatigue model and LPF analysis based on CLT.

Figure 22 plots the fatigue failure envelopes of MD laminates with lay-up configurations of [45/−45]4 and [0/90]4 in global biaxial stress space σx - σy, for various number of cycles to failure and r = 0.1. The fatigue failure envelopes are usually different for laminates with different configurations as shown in Figure 22. The biaxial fatigue strengths of the same laminate vary for different global biaxiality ratios. In addition, the biaxial fatigue strengths also vary with different laminates for the same global biaxiality ratios, for example, σx :σy = 1:0.2, as shown in Figure 22. The failure envelopes clearly show different load capacity ofthe laminates for different biaxiality ratios. For example, for the [45/−45]4 laminate, the load capacity under biaxial tension–tension or compression–compression is generally much better than that under tension–compression or compression–tension, and the failure is dominated by either the matrix or the fibers depending on the biaxiality ratios, as shown in Figure 22(a). For the [0/90]4 laminate, however, the load capacity is similar for different biaxiality ratios because the final failure is always dominated by the fibers, as shown in Figure 22(b). For the [45/−45]4 laminate, since the in-plane shear stress-strain relationship usually presents significant non-linearity for glass/epoxy fiber-reinforced composites, the secant in-plane shear modulus at failure strain is used in the LPF analysis.

The comparisons of failure envelopes from the fatigue model (r = 0.1) with the current test data (R = 0.1) for various number of cycles to failure are illustrated in Figure 23(a) and (b) for the [45/−45]4 and [0/90]4 laminates, respectively, where σx and σy correspond to the stresses along the horizontal and vertical directions in the tests. The predictions from the model show that the failures of the [45/−45]4 and [0/90]4 laminates under biaxial tension-compression loads are dominated by the matrix and the fibers, respectively, which agree with the experimental observations. It can be seen that the theoretical predictions for the [45/−45]4 laminate are in reasonably good agreement with the experimental results. For the [0/90]4 laminate, the predicted failure envelopes are a little more optimistic than test data. Usually, the failure of the [45/−45]4 laminate under biaxial tension–compression loads is dominated by the matrix and the failure strengths obtained from FPF analysis and LPF analysis are similar. For the [0/90]4 laminate under biaxial tension–compression loads, however, the failure is dominated by the fibers and failure strengths obtained from FPF and LPF analyses are quite different. The difference between the FPF and LPF analyses may cause optimistic predictions. The experimental results are supposed to be between predictions from the FPF and LPF analyses, and closer to predictions from the LPF analysis.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: A multi-axial fatigue model based on fatigue master curves and Puck’s criterion is developed for fatigue analysis of fiber-reinforced composite laminates in this article. The fatigue master curves from ATM are generated with limited uniaxial fatigue test data of UD laminates, and can be applied to fatigue loading conditions with different frequencies and stress ratios. Under fatigue loading, the uniaxial ply fatigue strengths are obtained through the fatigue master curves, and then the multi-axial fatigue failure is determined with these fatigue strengths by applying Puck’s criterion at the ply level. The traditional uniaxial S-N curve can be explicitly derived from the proposed fatigue model, and the multi-axial S-N curve is numerically determined with an equivalent fatigue stress by the fatigue model, where all stress components in the fatigue loadings are considered to account for the effects of multi-axiality. The fatigue model is also applicable to general MD laminates through analysis methods such as CLT or FEM. With several basic fatigue master curves for a ply material, fatigue strength of any laminate may be predicted by the multi-axial fatigue model for various frequencies, stress ratios, and multi-axiality ratios.

Limited uniaxial fatigue tests on glass/epoxy UD laminates were carried out to provide test data for establishing the fatigue master curves, and MD laminates were also tested under biaxial fatigue loadings. The application of the proposed multi-axial fatigue model is demonstrated with predictions of S-N curves and fatigue failure envelopes of UD and MD laminates. By using multi-axial S-N curves and fatigue failure envelopes, multi-axial fatigue failure can be illustrated with any number of cycles to failure and any group ofmulti-axiality ratios in a defined stress space. The multi-axial fatigue model can account for both local and global multi-axial failures. Two features of the multi-axial fatigue model are demonstrated:
Ply-level prediction of multi-axial fatigue failure, which means the model is easy to be used for laminates with various lay-up configurations.
Generation of fatigue failure envelope in stress spaces, which can clearly show the multi-axial failure and different failure modes, such as tension, compression or shear.

The fatigue of glass/epoxy UD and MD laminates with various lay-up configurations is investigated withthe proposed fatigue model. The predictions of uniaxial and multi-axial S-N curves with different stress ratios and multi-axiality ratios, for both local and global multi-axialities, from the proposed fatigue model are compared and validated with various test data. Fatigue failure envelopes are also generated for multi-axial loadings and compared with limited test data. Reasonably good agreement is observed between the results of prediction and experiment. Although the multi-axial fatigue model is demonstrated and validated with glass/epoxy laminates with uniform stress distribution, it can be extended to non-uniform stress distribution in structures, where the model can be coded into numerical analysis software.

ack.title: Acknowledgements
ack.p: Financial support from Vestas and NUS Incentive Grant is gratefully acknowledged.
